Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator proposes to study various aspects of index theory on singular spaces. The PI and his collaborators will, for example, apply their recent analysis of the resolution of the orbit space of a group action to the index theory of a family of equivariant operators. A similar resolution, but of an arbitrary pseudomanifold, will be used in a project to understand the properties of the signature operator and extend the class of spaces known to satisfy the Novikov conjecture from topology. A related project aims more generally to extend many of the methods of geometric microlocal analysis to the setting of stratified spaces. The PI will also work with his collaborators to understand the spectral geometry of non-compact or singular spaces, with projects to understand isospectrality for non-compact surfaces and extend the class of spaces where the topological Reidemeister torsion can be expressed analytically. Finally, the PI is involved in various efforts to extend the number of mathematicians aware of these results and working in this field, including the production of lecture notes and survey articles as well as the organization of conferences and seminars.

Singular spaces arise naturally in mathematics and physics, even when one is interested in studying smooth phenomena. For instance, recent models in cosmology and particle physics require an understanding of spaces with singularities such as corners and edges. However, many of the techniques used in geometric analysis do not apply to singular spaces. One aspect of this proposal is to contribute to the development and application of new techniques to problems arising in index theory and spectral geometry. These problems are in the intersection of analysis with other fields, such as topology, algebraic geometry, and mathematical physics, a confluence which is a source of both problems and applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:
Geometry studies many different types of spaces. Some are smooth like a sphere while other are singular with edges and corners, some are compact and some are unbounded with ends of infinite length. Smooth bounded spaces are the easiest to study but many applications, such as general relativity, require us to work on spaces with singularities or ends of infinite length.
The projects funded by this grant involved the relationship between the geometry and analysis of singular or unbounded spaces. Here geometry refers to properties like the presence and shape of the singularities and the way the space degenerates around the singularity while analysis refers to the behavior of functions and their derivatives on the space, particularly to their behavior at the singularities.
One of the projects made several important advances in understanding the `cohomology' of a singular space, an algebraic way of encoding the shape of a space. On a smooth space every object in cohomology can be represented uniquely by a well-behaved analytic object called a `harmonic form'. On a large class of singular spaces, it was shown that this representation can still be carried out by a delicate method of prescribing the behavior of the harmonic forms at the singularities.
Another project was inspired by a famous question, `Can you hear the shape of a drum?', which asks if the fundamental tones of a space, which are defined analytically, determine the geometry of the space. As opposed to smooth spaces, it is not clear when two non-smooth spaces should be thought of as having the same fundamental tones. In this project a definition was proposed that extends the notion for smooth spaces but makes sense for non-smooth spaces as well. Then it was shown that non-smooth surfaces with the same fundamental tones form a small set in an appropriate sense.
Other projects involved finding topological formulas for analytic objects on singular spaces (specifically `analytic torsion' and the `Fredholm index'). These are particularly interesting because of the different natures of topology and analysis. Analysis is in some ways rigid: if I change an equation a tiny bit it may no longer have solutions, or it might have many more than it used to. On the other hand, topology is flabby: it describes properties of a space that do not change under small changes that do not ‘tear’ or ‘smash’ the space. When a problem involves two such disparate fields, each approach brings its own tools and applications, making the results very powerful.
Broader impact:
The PI taught a graduate course on the mathematical techniques needed to make progress on this field of research. Lecture notes from this course are being developed and will result in an introductory textbook to facilitate the entry of young researchers. 
The PI co-organized an international conference to bring together researchers and disseminate problems and results. The conference resulted in a proceedings volume with interesting contributions form many leading researchers.
The PI worked together with the graduate director of his university in recruitment of students from underrepresented minorities in mathematics. This included participating in the annual conference of SACNAS, the society for the advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science, as well as the island-wide mathematics conference in Puerto Rico, SIDIM. Beyond recruiting individual students to the graduate program at Illinois, this served as an opportunity to make contacts with faculty at institutions at predominantly minority institutions. The PI followed up by making a recruitment trip to Puerto Rico, visiting the campus at Mayaguez and the campus at Rio Piedras of the University of Puerto Rico.
